_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Part 68.155 Executive Summary

The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements:

*     Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source.

*     The stationary source and regulated substances handled.

*     The worst case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distance for each reported scenario.

*     The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.

*     The five year accident history.

*     The emergency response program.

*     Planned changes to improve safety.


Part 68.155 Section A

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Decatur Utilities operates the Decatur Water Treatment Plant where chlorine is used for disinfection. Chlorine is the only regulated substance subject to the CRF 40 Part 68.

The company has in place annual mandatory chlorine safety training for all employees who work at the plant.

Additionally, specific training is required in all aspects of the operation of the chlorine process for those who operate the process. Training in maintenance and repair of the chlorine process equipment is conducted with all employees who are required to maintain and repair any part of the system.

Decatur Utilities has developed a Chlorine Emergency Response Program to fulfill the requirements of OSHA Part 1910.38. The emergency response program is coordinated with the local and state emergency response plan.


Part 68.155 Section B

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Water Treatment Plant has two stationary sources, one capable of holding 24 one-ton containers of chlorine and the other capable of holding 12 one-ton containers of chlorine. In process 1, the maximum of 48,000 pounds of chlorine gas may be stored

.  In process 2, a maximum of 24,000 pounds of chlorine gas may be stored. The covered processes consist of piping, as per Chlorine Institute pamphlet 6, Piping Systems for Dry Chlorine, and chlorine injection equipment specifically designed for the process.


Part 68.155 Section C

Worst Case and Alternative Case Scenarios

Decatur Utilities has used release scenarios for both worst case and alternative releases from, The Compliance Guidance and Model Risk Management Program for Water Treatment Plants, sponsored jointly by The American Water Works Association Research Foundation and The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Office of Research and Development, and published by AWWA in 1998*. Additionally, the rate of release and endpoints corresponding to the above scenarios were derived from EPA CEPP, RMP Series, Risk Management for Wastewater Treatment Plants.** 

Worst Case Release Scenarios

This scenario was modeled as a direct release over a 10 minute period, as required by the regulations. It involves catastrophic failure of a one ton container due to impact, corrosion, or construction defect. The entire contents of a full container, 2,000 pounds, is released over a ten minute period at a rate of 200 pounds per minute.* The toxic endpoint was modeled as 1.3 mile radius in all directions from the point of release.** The affected population was estimated at 910.***

Alternative Case Release Scenario

This scenario assumes release of chlorine gas through 20 feet of 1 inch schedule 80 pipe due to complete failure of the pipe. The scenario assumes that the pressure in the pipe is approximately 97.5 pounds per square inch, which is the vapor pressure of chlorine at 77 degrees F. It also assumes that the release is limited by the pipe dimensions and not by any valve or opening upstream of the release. The release duration is 60 minutes at an average release rate of 72 lb/min. The total release is 4,320 pounds with a toxic endpoint of 0.8 miles. The pop

ulation is estimated at 560.


Part 155.68 Section D

Prevention Program Elements

Management System

Decatur Utilities has documented a management system and has assigned overall responsibility for development and implementation of the Risk Management Program to a qualified individual. The management system clearly delineates accountability and responsibility of specific elements of the program to various RMP management groups.


Process Safety Information

Current process safety information is available to all operators of the covered process and maintenance employees in accordance with CRF 40 Part 68.48. Safety information includes current MSDS sheets, maximum intended inventory, safe upper and lower temperatures, pressures, and flows, process equipment and material specifications, safe operating procedures and codes and standards used in the design and construction of the process.


Process Hazard Analysis

A hazard analysis has been performed for the program II covered processes. A checklist was used based on The Chlorine Institute's, The Chlorine manual, pamphlet 1 6th edition, January 1997. Causes of potential accidental release scenarios were investigated and safeguards in place to prevent a release. The process hazard analysis was documented and will be updated every five years.


Operating Procedures

Process operating procedures were reviewed, documented, and refresher training conducted with all plant operators and maintenance employees. Operating procedures cover all phases of process operations including system startup, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and startup following an emergency shutdown. Process limits were reviewed and documented. Emergency first aid care for chlorine exposures are outlined and included in training.


Training

Chlorine safety training and Red Cross first aid and CPR training is mandatory for all plant employees and is conducted annually. Other mandatory training is condu

cted  every 3 years for all plant operators and maintenance employees and includes emergency first aid for chlorine exposures, process safe upper and lower limits, chlorine response plan, operating procedures, and safe loading/unloading of one ton containers. Training for all maintenance employees is conducted every 3 years and covers process and chlorinator maintenance and repair, chlorine piping specifications, and management of change procedures. Documentation of employee attendance at all training sessions are maintained for a period of not less than 5 years.



Mechanical Integrity

All process equipment, piping, ventilation system, monorail and hoist have a documented schedule of inspection and preventive and periodic maintenance. All maintenance inspection and testing on chlorine process equipment is conducted as per manufacturer's recommendations and is consistent with accepted engineering practices. Any deficiencies identified during such maintenance and inspection are addressed in a safe and prompt manner.


Part 68.58

Compliance Audits

Compliance audits are conducted every 3 years in accordance with this part. The audit is conducted by a team of at least 3 persons, one of whom is knowledgeable in the process. A report of the audit findings is generated following the audit and all deficiencies or recommendations are promptly addressed and the resolution is documented. The two most recent audits are maintained at the facility.


Part 68.60

Incident Investigation

Specific incident investigation reporting and documentation procedures have been implemented and are followed in accordance with this part in response to any incident involving a covered process that did or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of chlorine gas. The incident investigation is conducted as soon as possible but no later than 48 hours following the incident. Following the investigation a summary report is generated and includes, at a minimum, th

e following information: date of incident, date the investigation began, description of the incident and any contributing factors, and any corrective action or recommendations resulting from the investigation.


Part 68.155 Section E

Five-Year Accident History

An accidental release is defined in part 68.42 Section A as having resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. Decatur Utilities has had no accidental release within the past five years.


Part 68.155 Section F

Emergency Response Program

Decatur Utilities has in place an emergency response plan that is coordinated with both state and local emergency response plans, (LEPC). Additionally, a specific plan has been developed for chlorine emergencies that follows OSHA standard 1910.38. The plan is reviewed and training is conducted with all plant operators add maintenance employees every 3 years. The plan includes comprehensive procedures for onsite emergencies and is designed to coordinate with the state and local emergency response plan.


Part 68.155 Section G

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

No changes needed at this time.
